texts.shortText: Carapace flattened, transversely ovate, gastric region slightly raised, dorsal surface with fine granules giving a sharkskin-like texture. Frontal region squarish, projecting forward, eyes hidden dorsally. Margins of carapace with 2-3 sets of minute granules around the edge. Pterygostomial region has large, flat-topped granules closely together, separated by deep crevices. Carapace mostly white/cream and often mottled with orange/red blotches or smaller spots. Chelipeds and walking legs mostly white/cream, though occasionally coloured darker orange.
Carapace length up to 9 mm, width around 11 mm.

Global: South Africa, India.

Local/Regional: From False Bay to Mozambique.

This shallow-water species is often encountered in the intertidal under stones, within shell deposits where it is exceptionally cryptic. They have also been observed on free-floating seaweeds that accumulate in the surf zone.
Not specifically known for this species, though many leucosid crabs are scavengers, while some are ambush predators that feed on small crustaceans.

Not specifically known for this species, though for others in the family males transfer sperm to the female via the spermatophore, and eggs are either released and fertilised on their way out, or fertilization happens internally as some species have a brooding chamber for the eggs to develop.
One of four species in the genus . It was recently moved by Poore & Ahyong (2023) from the subfamily Cryptocneminae Stimpson 1907 to the Ebaliinae Stimpson, 1871.

Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 132).

Emmerson, WD (2016). A Guide to, and Checklist for, the Decapoda of Namibia, South Africa and Mozambique. Newcastle upon Tyne: Cambridge Scholars Publishing. Volumes 1 – 3, 526, 645, 711 pp.

Poore, GC & Ahyong, ST (2023). Marine Decapod Crustacea: A Guide to Families and Genera of the World. CSIRO publishing.
